metadata.case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh v. Ramprasad

facts.text: Ram Prasad was living with his mistress Mst. Rajji at Mannaur in District Panna. Evidence shows that they were having quarrels for some time previous to the incident.

On May 24, 1963, Ram Prasad intended leaving Mannaur for Harsa because his cattle used to be stolen at Mannaur. Mst. Rajji was unwilling to go unless he first reported the matter to the police or left her cattle for maintenance.
On the night of May 24, 1963, Ram Prasad ordered a van and began putting his luggage to leave for Harsa. Mst. Rajji brought village panchas for intercession.
Panchas witnessed disagreement: Ram Prasad insisted on taking her, Rajji resisted.
Ram Prasad approached Mannulal PW4 with lantern in one hand and aluminium bowl in other, asked for kerosene oil as lamp oil run down, but denied.
Immediately after, cry heard from Mst. Rajji that Ram Prasad put kerosene on her and set her alight. Panchas including Mannulal, Holke arrived, put out fire; extensive burns.
Mst. Rajji accused Ram Prasad; he did not protest, retorted she was his wife, panchas had nothing to do, they might get him hanged.
Mst. Rajji taken to police station first (insisted), made statement Ex. P-7 charging Ram Prasad with putting kerosene and setting fire.
Then to hospital; stated to Dr. Mrs. Ghosh and Dr. M.L. Gupta that burnt by husband who put kerosene. Dr. Ghosh noted 'homicidal burn by husband'.
Mst. Rajji died the next day.
Sessions Judge convicted under s.324 IPC, RI 6 months.
State appealed acquittal u/s 302 IPC and revision for enhancement.
High Court convicted u/s 304 Part II, 4 years RI; revision dismissed as infructuous. Judgment dated October 20, 1964 in Criminal Appeal No. 67 of 1964.
Burnt clothes and aluminium bowl smelt of kerosene, noted by Sessions Judge.
Jhallu PW4 (hostile) stated Mst. Rajji said quarrel settled, but police statement differed.

legal_issues.text: Whether the offence committed by Ram Prasad was under s.302 IPC (murder) or lower, such as s.304 Part II or s.324 IPC.
Whether Ram Prasad poured kerosene and set Mst. Rajji alight, or she committed suicide falsely accusing him.

petitioner_arguments.text: Conviction should have been under s.302 IPC; failure of justice requiring interference.

respondent_arguments.text: Mst. Rajji herself put kerosene and set fire, committed suicide falsely charging Ram Prasad.
No proof of kerosene from medical reports as wounds did not smell of kerosene.

court_reasoning.text: Accepted prosecution evidence: quarrel proved, panchas reliable, Ram Prasad asked for kerosene immediately before incident, no protest by him, three dying declarations consistent, conduct suspicious.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ram Prasad responsible for pouring kerosene and setting alight.

court_reasoning.text: Burns extensive and grievous. Death caused by criminal act. Applies s.300 fourthly: act imminently dangerous, known to likely cause death or injury likely to cause death, no excuse for risk.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Pouring kerosene and setting clothes on fire is so imminently dangerous that it must in all probability cause death.

court_reasoning.text: Kerosene use proved by smell on clothes/bowl, witnesses; medical omission immaterial.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Evidence satisfactory that kerosene poured before fire set.

holdings.text: Offence falls within fourthly of s.300 IPC: culpable homicide amounting to murder u/s 302 IPC.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Determining offence: from simple hurt by burning (324) to grievous (326) to culpable homicide not murder (304 Pt II) to murder (302 via 300 clauses, esp. fourthly)

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed. Conviction under s.304 Part II substituted with conviction under s.302 IPC. Sentence altered to imprisonment for life.
outcome.relief_granted: Conviction and sentence enhanced to s.302 IPC, life imprisonment

key_quotes.text: "culpable homicide is murder if the person committing the act knows that it is so imminently dangerous that it must in all probability, cause death or such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, and commits such act without any excuse for incurring the risk"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Application of s.300 fourthly to facts

key_quotes.text: "It is obvious that there was no excuse for Ram Prasad to have taken the risk of causing the death or such bodily injury as was likely to cause death."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key to holding act as murder

key_quotes.text: "No special knowledge is needed to know that one may cause death by burning if he sets fire to the clothes of a person."
key_quotes.speaker: court
